content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

Here is an example of how you could define a `show` method for the `FloatWithUnits` struct in Julia:
```
struct FloatWithUnits
    value::Float64
    unit::String
end

function Base.show(io::IO, x::FloatWithUnits)
    print(io, x.value, " ", x.unit)
end
```
This method defines a `show` function for the `FloatWithUnits` struct that takes an input stream `io` and a `FloatWithUnits` object `x`. It then prints the value and unit of the object to the output stream, separated by a space.

To use this method, you can create an instance of the `FloatWithUnits` struct and call the `show` function on it:
```
julia> x = FloatWithUnits(1.8, "meters")
julia> show(x)
"1.8 meters"
```
This will output the value and unit of the object to the console, separated by a space.
